metadata.sermon_start_end: Jesus healed ten lepers. The story is familiar to us. Lepers were dangerous outsiders who were excluded from normal society. They asked him for mercy. He authorized them to be “made clean” so that they could be readmitted to society. We are not told how he cleansed them [...] Give it away; it’s free; give it away and be grateful. Give it away, because more healing gifts will be given. Give it away, and don’t get leprosy!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon begins with Luke 17 but quickly shifts to 2 Kings 5. While it focuses on the narrative of Naaman, it treats the text more as a moral example of 'insiders vs outsiders' rather than identifying what is unique to this text that can be found nowhere else. It uses the Bible passage as a springboard for a general theme of grace versus monetization.
quotes: Behind this story, however, is an older, longer story about healing a leper.
The story is about the prophet and his transformative power.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify the specific theological 'novum' of 2 Kings 5—perhaps the tension between the soil of Israel and the house of Rimmon—rather than reducing it to a general lesson on generosity.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates knowledge of the historical-political context (Syria as enemy, Naaman's rank, the role of the Jordan). However, there is no evidence of engagement with the original languages or deeper biblical theology of the prophetic office beyond narrative retelling.
quotes: In that story the foreigner is a big-time political general in Syria. Syria is Israel’s long-term enemy...
He knows that when the national holidays come around, he must go to the temple along with the king, and worship the god of Syria whose name is Rimmon.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exegesis by exploring the significance of the 'seven times' washing or the theological weight of the 'two mules' burden of earth' (which was omitted) to show the radicality of YHWH's presence.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is somewhat general. While it mentions 'gays, immigrants, or Muslims' at the start, the later application falls into generalities about 'business models' and 'common good'. It lacks the sharp, concrete socio-political or personal application Dekker demands.
quotes: We might say he was a despised outsider, like we have sometimes thought about gays, or immigrants, or Muslims.
God’s goodness is not subject to a 'business model.' Give it away; it’s free...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond metaphors like 'business model' to specific instances where the congregation 'monetizes' grace or acts out of 'scarcity' in their local context.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a block structure: Exposition (I, II, III) followed by Application (IV). This separation is exactly what Dekker warns against, as it keeps the hearer as an observer of the text for too long before being 'expounded' by it.
quotes: But we have not yet come to the telling part of the story.
IV. The story is about the prophet... But by the end the key character is Gehazi.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the critique of the 'insider' (Gehazi) throughout the retelling of the story so the hearer is implicated from the beginning.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The themes of misery (leprosy/anxiety) and redemption (free healing) are present. Gratitude is the central theme. However, the 'misery' is treated more as a psychological or social condition (scarcity) than a theological state before God.
quotes: This is a story of a great sad reversal from health to leprosy.
He got the leprosy that matched his anxious action.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Sharpen the 'misery' aspect by emphasizing that the 'insider's' entitlement is a form of spiritual death, not just a social mistake.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon effectively uses the figure of Gehazi to present the 'two ways.' The warning of 'getting leprosy' functions as a serious call to choice, acknowledging the possibility of being lost in time through anxiety and greed.
quotes: Gehazi must have been scared that he would not have enough... And he got the leprosy that matched his anxious action.
Give it away, and don’t get leprosy!
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Clarify the 'eternal' dimension of this loss to ensure the hearer feels the full weight of the choice between the way of grace and the way of Gehazi.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned at the beginning but disappears for the majority of the sermon. While 'grace' is the theme, Christ is not the explicit 'telos' of the 2 Kings exposition. The sermon becomes more about a general principle of generosity than the person of Christ.
quotes: So with Jesus. He healed ten. He showed that there was plenty of healing.
The one Lord who is central in the sermon is Christ. [Thesis 7 reference - missing in sermon body]
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'free gift' of Elisha to the finished work of Christ, showing that Christ is the only reason the 'pardon' for the house of Rimmon is possible.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1750 words, the sermon likely clocks in under 20 minutes if delivered at a measured pace. According to Dekker, it lacks the 'breadth' required for true depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the theological reflection on the 'house of Rimmon' or the nature of the prophetic word to reach the 20-minute threshold of 'depth'.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon functions primarily as a narrative retelling with a moral application regarding generosity versus scarcity. It falls short of Dekker's criteria by separating exposition from application and failing to maintain Christ as the explicit telos. The specificity of the 2 Kings text is sacrificed for a general lesson on 'insiders' and 'outsiders.'
strengths: Effective use of the Gehazi narrative to illustrate the danger of entitlement.
Clear identification of the 'two ways' through the contrast between Naaman's peace and Gehazi's leprosy.
Adequate historical-political framing of the Naaman story.
weaknesses: Insufficient duration (under 20 minutes) limits the potential for theological depth.
Christ is treated as an introductory example rather than the center and goal of the entire proclamation.
The application remains in the realm of general 'social attitudes' rather than concrete spiritual or congregational reality.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate moral exhortation, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the strict sense of Dekker’s theses. It lacks the necessary interwoveness of text and hearer, and the Christological focus is too peripheral.
